She is hoping to improve their standard of living through the income she gets from her retail shop and hog raising business.

loans.use: to buy stock for her general store

loans.name: Gladys

texts.en:
Gladys is 33 years old and has a child who goes to elementary school. Aside from farming, she also runs a sari-sari (variety) store to make additional income. She sells grocery items to the people in her village. Through farming, she earns a yield twice a year amounting to P25,000. Her spouse plows the farm land and Gladys helps transplant rice seedlings. As they cannot do all the activities, they need additional laborers. So she is asking for a loan of P10,000 to buy seeds and pay laborers to help transplant rice seedlings. 

In the future, she would like to achieve an abundant harvest every cropping season to save for the college education of her child.

loans.use: to buy seeds and pay farm laborers who help in transplanting rice seedlings in the field.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase wheat seeds and fertilizers

loans.name: Swasembada Group

texts.en: Riana is 33 years old. She is pictured in the middle of the photo. She is married with one child. For the past 7 years she has been selling coconuts in front of her house to help provide more income for her family. She wants to now start selling children's clothing as a second business and she will use the loan for this. She hopes that, with this loan, she can have her own children's clothing store. She also hopes that over time her business will grow and that some day her family will have enough savings to go on a pilgrimage to Mecca(Hajj).

loans.use: to pay for children's clothes to sell in her store

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy farm inputs.

loans.name: Gavaadondov

texts.en:
Gavaadondov is 28 years old and lives with her sisters and father in a 'ger' in Uvurhangai province of Mongolia. Her older sister has a private business and her younger sister is a doctor at the local hospital. Her father builds brick fireplaces and walls and is very respected for his work in the town. 

Gavaadondov attended beauty care training in 2006. However, she has worked as a beauty stylist since 1997. In April 2011, she established her own beauty salon and rented a commercial space for her new business. She took four business loans from XacBank beforehand and used them to expand her business. She already has many regular clients. 

She is planning to improve her business and sell beauty and cosmetic products. She is requesting a 3,500,000 MNT loan to purchase beauty products from ICS Firm, a Korean brand, for her salon.

loans.use: To purchase beauty products from ICS Firm, a Korean brand.

loans.name: Gohar

texts.en:
Gohar is a widow and she is 62 years old. Gohar lives in Vanadzor city with her daughter and two under-aged grandchildren. 

More than 6 years ago Gohar established her own business, which allows her to provide her family. Gohar sells men’s and women’s clothes, outerwear and handbags as well. She buys merchandise from a neighbor country and sells it at her shop.  Her daughter takes care of her children and helps Gohar as far as possible. 

Gohar is seeking a 1,000,000 AMD loan to buy some outwear and autumn clothes for her business.  This is Gohar’s 4th loan from Nor Horizon and she has never delayed her repayments.

loans.use: To buy some outwear and autumn clothes for her business.

loans.name: 13.75 Thiệu Đô Group

texts.en:
Mrs Thoa operates a food stall selling meat. She is requesting a loan to purchase cattle to butcher to sell meat.

Thoa is 48 years old and she is married with four children. Thoa is the group leader of the 13.75 Thiệu Đô solidarity group, which consists of six members. She lives and works in Thieu Hoa district, a semi-urban area in Thanh Hoa province, with two dependents.

This is Thoa's first loan with Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. Thoa has been involved in this business for more than 10 years. The main hardship that Thoa faces in her business is the lack of capital.

In future, Thoa hopes for her business to do well, to be able to buy more supplies and equipment for her business, and for her children to find a good job.

loans.use: to purchase cattle to butcher to sell meat.

loans.name: Usaha Jaya 5 Group

texts.en:
Maryati is 43 years old. She is married with one son. In the picture she is the one wearing the white headscarf. A year ago she began selling "krupuk" (Indonesian crackers) in front of her house and through her neighbors' stalls. Now she needs a loan to buy more "krupuk" to expand the business from one kilogram to two kilograms per day. 

The income from her "krupuk" business supplements what her husband makes. She hopes that someday she and her husband will have enough savings to buy a home because they currently rent. She also hopes that having more income in the family will help her son someday obtain a commercial driving license so he can have a job.

loans.use: to pay for "krupuk" (Indonesian crackers) to resell in food stalls.

loans.name: 3.13.76.thiệu Đô Group

texts.en:
Mrs Huệ has a retail business selling dry food. She is requesting a loan to purchase processed seafood to resell.

Huệ is 43 years old and she is married with 4 children.  Huệ is the group leader of the 3.13.76. Thiệu Đô solidarity group, which consists of 4 members. She lives and works in Thieu Hoa district, a semi-urban area in Thanh Hoa province, with one dependent. This is Huệ's first loan with Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women.

Huệ has been involved in this business for 7 years. The main hardship that Huệ faces in her business is not being able to meet the high demands for products.

With her business profit, Huệ hopes to make enough money to provide for her kids, to buy land of her own and for her children to find a good job.

loans.use: to purchase processed seafood to resell

loans.name: Patrick

texts.en:
Patrick is a 29-year-old married man with two children living in his own house in Fort Portal, Uganda. His dream is to own a fully-fledged video hall (small cinema showing videos or television broadcasts) in the next three years. 

For five years he has been into videography and photography and the business is still booming. His major challenge has been unsettled debts and limited space in his business premises. Patrick needs the loan to complete building his video hall.

loans.use: to complete building his video hall

loans.name: Annet

texts.en:
Annet is 28 years old and lives in the town of Kibuli in the Kampala South region of Uganda. For the past 5 years, Annet has been working hard to manage her stationary store, which sells school supplies and electronics. 

To help expand her business, Annet has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more commodities to put in the business like exercise books and will help Annet to generate greater profits and expand her business. Annet hopes that in the future she will be able to start more side businesses. 

Annet is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Annet who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to purchase more commodities to put in the business like exercise books

loans.name: Wilma

texts.en:
Wilma is married with 5 grown children. She is 56 years old and lives in Aurora, Zamboanga Del Sur, Philippines.

Wilma is planting coconut trees and bananas for sale. She has traded the said crops for over 20 years and made favorable returns. Her spouse works as a carpenter but his work is impermanent in nature.

At the end of every month, Wilma earns an approximate total of 5,680 PHP considering all these sources. She has requested a loan of 45,000 PHP from GDMPC to purchase fertilizers to enhance the growth of crops and for a high potential of return on investment.

Wilma is a GDMPC member, joining this year. This is her first loan transaction made in the cooperative. In the future, Wilma hopes to expand the cultivated area and raise more of these plants to gain more. She also plans to repair some portions of her house to live comfortably.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers

loans.name: Domingo

texts.en:
Domingo is 60 years old and a married man who has three children. At his age, he still enjoys raising pigs for fattening because he would like to send his children into higher levels of education.

Domingo had been engaged in the hog raising business for 20 years and he is grateful because he is able to maintain his business through the income he obtained.

He would like to ask for additional capital in the amount of 15,000 PHP to be use in buying three piglets and a supply of feed for his livestock business. He hopes that he could obtain this amount to further increase his profit for the education of his two children. He would be thankful if he could improve his business and their standard way of living.

loans.use: to purchase three pigs and feed for his livestock business

loans.name: Muhamed

texts.en:
Muhamed is 44 years old, married, and has five children living in his own house in Fort Portal, Uganda. His dream is to construct a bigger permanent house for his family. 

He is a mechanic for motorcycles, motor vehicles and bicycles and has been in this business for 10 years now. His major constraint has been the constant rise in prices for spare parts and his goal is to set up a full fledged garage. 

Muhamed needs the Kiva loan to buy batteries and lubricants.

loans.use: To buy batteries and lubricants.

loans.name: Betty

texts.en:
Betty, 54, is the single mother of five children age 13 to 30 living in Hoima, Uganda.

Ever since she separated from her husband, she has been taking care of her children alone. 

For 30 years she has been operating a bar business. She faces a challenge in the high rate of bottle breakages and her dream is to move into a bigger business premise and own a hotel. 

Betty needs a loan to stock beer, spirits and soft drinks for sale.

loans.use: to buy beer, soft drinks and spirits for sale.

loans.name: 3.11.78 Thiệu Ngọc Group

texts.en:
Sen is 42 years old. She is married and has two children.

Sen is the group leader of the 3.11.78 Thiệu Ngọc solidarity group, which consists of three members.
 
She lives and works in the Thieu Hoa district, a semi-urban area in Thanh Hoa province.

Sen works in agriculture, raising poultry and cattle. She has been involved in this business for six years. The main hardship that Sen faces in her business is the lack of capital. 

She is requesting a loan to purchase calves to raise and sell in the future. This is Sen's first loan with Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.

With her business profit, Sen hopes to make enough money to provide for her children, to be able to buy more supplies and equipment for her business, and for her business to do well.

loans.use: to purchase calves to raise and sell in the future.

loans.name: Enock

texts.en:
Enock is a 48-year-old married man with four children, and he owns a house in Kasese, Uganda.

He has been buying and selling beans and maize for five years, and this has helped him in educating his children. 

His hardships are price fluctuations and bad debtors, and his vision is a bigger and well established food store and an educated, poverty-free family.

Enock needs the loan to buy maize and beans for resale.

loans.use: To buy maize and beans.

loans.name: Jannifer

texts.en:
Jannifer is 32 years old and lives in the town of Kibuli in the Kampala South region of Uganda. She is single and has one child. For the past five years, Jannifer has been working hard to manage her small shop, which sells clothes. 

To help expand her business, Jannifer has requested a loan of 1,500,000 UGX from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more clothes and stock for her business, and it will help Jannifer to generate greater profits and expand her business. Jannifer hopes that in the future she will be able to have a booming business and start other businesses. 

Jannifer is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Jannifer who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans but have businesses that have grown too large for micro-loans.

loans.use: to buy more clothes and stock for her business.

loans.name: 3.9.81 Thiệu Dương Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Minh has a retail business selling dry food. She is requesting a loan to purchase processed seafood to resell.

Minh is 34 years old and she is married with three children. Minh is the group leader of the 3.9.81 Thiệu D. solidarity group, which consists of five members. She lives and works in Thieu Hoa district, a semi-urban area in Thanh Hoa province, with her three dependents.

In 2010, Minh joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to improve her  business. Minh has successfully repaid two loans from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. Minh has been involved in this business for 4 years. The main hardship that Minh faces in her business is not being able to meet the high demands for her products.

With her business profit, Minh hopes to make enough money to provide for her kids, to maintain her business, and for her family to be healthy and happy.

loans.use: to purchase processed seafood to resell.

loans.name: Tserendolgor

texts.en:
Tserendolgor is 32 years old and lives with her two sons and husband in a 'ger', a Mongolian yurt, in Uvurhangai province of Mongolia. Her elder son is a high school student. The younger son attends the local kindergarten. She started her business in 2008 by selling clothes and goods at the local market. She has many years of business experience. 

She is planning to buy a new container in which she stores the goods and sells the goods. She has taken out four business loans from XacBank. She uses her loans for the right purposes and business deals. Her sales income and business profits are increasing gradually in the last few years. She is a hard-working and diligent woman who says "I want to expand my business and buy a new container." She is requesting a 700,000 MNT loan to purchase more clothes and to increase her turnover capital.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes.

loans.name: Agnes Mary

texts.en:
Agnes Mary  is 38 years old and lives in the town of Kibuli in the Kampala South region of Uganda. She is single and has two children with one of them currently in school. For the past three years, Agnes Mary  has been working hard to manage her small retail business, which sells assorted goods. 

To help expand her business, Agnes Mary  has requested a loan of 1,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to increase her stock of assorted goods and will help Agnes Mary  to generate greater profits and expand her business. Agnes Mary  hopes that in the future she will be able to start up an extra business. 

Agnes Mary  is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Agnes Mary  who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for micro-loans.

loans.use: to increase her stock of assorted goods.

loans.name: 3.9.80 Thiệu Dương Group

texts.en:
Mrs Quyền works in agriculture, farming poultry and cattle. She is requesting a loan to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in future.

Quyền is 54 years old and she is married with four children. Quyền is the group leader of the 3.9.80 Thiệu D. solidarity group, which consists of five members. She lives and works in Thieu Hoa district, a semi-urban area in Thanh Hoa province, with no dependents.

In 2010, Quyền joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to improve her  business. Quyền has successfully repaid two loans from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. Quyền has been involved in this business for more than 10 years. The main hardship that Quyền faces in her business is the lack of capital.

With her business profit, Quyền hopes to buy a motorbike. She hopes for her children to find a good job and to be able to buy more supplies and equipment for her business.

loans.use: purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in future.

loans.name: Kitonga

texts.en:
Kitonga, 30 years old, is married with three children. Two are in school. He does mixed farming, i.e., rearing sheep, goats, cattle and is also a wheat farmer which he has been doing for the past eight years.


He learned about KADET LTD  through a KADET staff member. He has applied for his first loan which he plans to spend on farming and also to purchase more animals.

He hopes to make profit and use the anticipated profit to educate his children. He dreams of expanding his business.

loans.use: to spend on farming and also buy more animals to rear.

loans.name: Maher

texts.en:
Maher is a 32-year-old married man with one child.

He has worked as a mechanic for 16 years. He started working early because he had to help his family to cover expenses.

Maher is a hard-working man. He seeks the best in everything. He always updates his machines and tools to keep his work professional. Most of his customers are friends, relatives and neighbors.

He is requesting a loan from Al Majmoua, a Kiva partner, for the second time, in order to buy a new car lift, necessary for his business. He is a good standing borrower that Al Majmoua is proud to deal with, just as his customers are.

Maher hopes to expand his working place and to open new branch in the future.

loans.use: To buy a new car lift for his business.

loans.name: Sadar Jaya Group

texts.en:
Agus is 33 years old, married, and has four children. He has an 8 year old, a 5 year old, and 3-month-old twins. 

He has been a florist for five years in a local market. His business has been doing well, but he wants to use the loan to expand it by buying more flowers and different types of flowers so he has more variety in the stall. In the future he hopes to have a large flower store.

The income from the stall helps pay for educational expenses and health care for his children. His hope for his children is that they all can go to school.

loans.use: to buy more flowers to resell in his stall at the market.

loans.name: Phiona

texts.en:
Phiona is 25 years old and lives in the town of Kibuli in the Kampala South region of Uganda. For the past four years, Phiona has been working hard to manage her small shop, which rents videos to customers. 

To help expand her business, Phiona has requested a loan of 1,500,000 UGX from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy another computer to help her do other work, like secretarial services, and video movies. And it will help Phiona to keep track of rentals and to excel in her studies. Phiona hopes that in the future she will be able to set up another video rental store in town. 

Phiona is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Phiona who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for micro-loans.

loans.use: to buy another computer for keeping track of video rentals

loans.name: Simet

texts.en:
Simet is 35 years old and married. The couple has seven children; five sons and two daughters. Four are in school, one stays at home, one is hired to work in chicken farming and another one is still young. The family is living in a village along National Road Number Five, approximately 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh City.
 
Simet sells fish in the local market. Her husband, Theng, 37, is a rice farmer. Additionally, he also drives a motor remoque taxi when he is free from farming. A remoque is a motorbike with a trailer at the back.

Simet is asking for a loan of $1,000 to replace her husband's old trailer because it breaks.

loans.use: To replace her husband's old trailer.

loans.name: Ali

texts.en:
Ali is 45 years old and lives in the town of Kibuli in the Kampala South region of Uganda. He is married and has eight children with six of them currently in school. 

For the past five years, Ali has been working hard to manage his poultry business, which sells chickens in the local market. 

To help expand his business, Ali has requested a loan of 1,500,000 UGX from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more birds and will help Ali to generate greater profits and improve the standard of living for his family. 

Ali hopes that in the future he will be able to open up another poultry business. 

Ali is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Ali who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans but have businesses that have grown too large for micro-loans.

loans.use: to buy more poultry.

loans.name: Sokhoeun

texts.en:
Sokhoeun (pictured here) produces hammocks and sells them to a middleman who comes to buy them at her home. Her husband, Chim, sells piglets. They have three children, one son and two daughters. One is married and other two are in school. They live in a village along National Road Number Five, about twenty kilometers from Phnom Penh City. 

Sokhoeun is asking for a loan of $1,000 to help provide capital for her husband to purchase additional piglets for sale.

loans.use: To help her husband to purchase additional piglets for sale.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy onions, Maggi, salt, rice, etc., in bulk.

loans.name: Try

texts.en:
Try (pictured above), 48, is a construction worker. His wife, 39, stays at home and does housework. They have three children--one son and two daughters. Two are garment workers and the other is still young. The family lives in a suburb of Phnom Penh, about fifteen kilometers away. 

Try is asking for his first loan in the amount of $1,000 to purchase a motorbike for his children to drive to work.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for his children to drive to work.

loans.name: Stanley

texts.en:
Stanley is 32 years old and lives in the town of Kibuli in the Kampala South region of Uganda. He is married and has three children with two of them currently in school. For the past five years, Stanley has been working hard to manage his poultry business. He sells chickens in the local market. 

To help expand his business, Stanley has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more birds and will help Stanley to generate greater profits and improve the standard of living for his family. Stanley hopes that in the future he will be able to open up another business. 

Stanley is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Stanley who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for micro-loans.

loans.use: to buy more poultry.

loans.name: Bunthy

texts.en:
Bunthy is a "Tuk Tuk" taxi driver. His wife stays at home and does housework. They have three daughters. One is in school and other two are still young. The family is living about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh City 

Bunthy is asking for a loan of $1,000 to buy new "Tuk Tuk" to replace the old one. 

Photo: Bunthy is standing in front of the "Tuk Tuk" which he wanted to buy. He bought it, but he did not give any money yet. So, he is asking for the loan to pay for purchasing it.

loans.use: To buy a new "Tuk Tuk" (vehicle with sidecar) to replace the old one.

loans.name: Mtakuja Group

texts.en:
Zena, who is in her late 30's, is married with one child who goes to school.  She also takes care of her younger sister who goes to school.  She has had a grocery business for one year.  She works from 1p.m. to 5p.m. daily and is able to make a fair monthly profit.

This will be her second loan from Tujijenge Tanzania.  She used the previous loan to buy items that were missing from the grocery.  She has paid back her loan successfully.  She would like a loan to increase on the grocery inventory.  Her dream is to one day be able to buy a land.

She will share this loan with her loan group Mtakuja, which has a total of 16 members.  They will hold each other accountable for paying back their loans.  (1st person on the left front row is a child and does not belong to the loan group.)

loans.use: to increase the inventory at her grocery store.

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
Jane is 41 years old and married with four children aged between 25 and 15 with the last born still in school.  She has been in farming for 20 years producing cabbage, maize, potatoes, carrots, and beans which are all sold to the local market.

Jane has made a loan request of 30,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase poultry birds for a poultry farming business.  She says the poultry business will give her security when her farm crops fail due to poor rains.  She adds that she will also use the income to educate her youngest child.

Jane notes that animal diseases and poor market prices for produce are the challenges in the farming business.

loans.use: to purchase poultry birds.

loans.name: Hassan

texts.en:
Hassan is 50 years old and married with two children, ages 18 and 30.  He runs a used clothing store in Kissy which is a neighborhood in Freetown.  He also takes care of two relatives.

Hassan has owned this business for 30 years.  He also earns income from renting out a house.  He says that the main challenge to his business is that during heavy rain, sales are slow.

He requested this loan through BRAC Sierra Leone to purchase used clothes for sale.  Hassan says that the extra income from this loan will help him improve immensely.  In the future, he would like to begin importing goods oversea.

loans.use: To purchase more used clothes items.

loans.name: Layla

texts.en:
Layla is a 47-year-old married woman. She opened a grocery store in 2009 in order to do something useful, as she said, and to help her husband in covering their expenses.

Layla is a smart woman. She works on improving herself as much as she can, in addition to expanding her business since she started.

She requested a loan from A. Majmoua, a Kiva partner, for the first time, in order to increase her business capitA. by increasing her merchandise to fulfill her customers' needs and reply to their requests.

Layla is a hardworking woman. She sells food, beverages, vegetables and sweets. She will also add new products, attracting customers. She will work hard on expanding her working place and might add a butchery zone.

loans.use: To increase her merchandise.

loans.name: Judy

texts.en:
Judy is 22, married and has one child aged six. She has been farming in Nyamira, South Rift, Kenya for five years. She currently employs two farmhands and produces tea, maize and milk for the local market. She also runs a retail shop in the local market for additional income. Judy says hail and drought are the main challenges to her farming.

Judy has made a loan request for 47,100 KES through Kiva’s partner Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. She says she will use the extra income to educate her child, improve her farm and shop and even hopes to open a cereals grinding business.

loans.use: to purchase and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Ezekiel

texts.en:
Ezekiel is 38 years old and has been in farming for 10 years. His farm produces tea (which goes to Kenya Tea Development Authority), as well as milk, maize, and bananas, which he sells to the local market. He is married with three children between 2 and 13 years of age.

Ezekiel has requested a loan of 47,100 Kenya shillings (KES) from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. He says the loan will improve his farming business, the profits of which will help him in educating his children and improve their living standards. He is optimistic with his farming business and focuses on buying more land for farming.

He says fluctuation in rain is a challenge, causing flooding at times and drought at others.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy products like shoes, clothes, trousers, and caps in bulk.

loans.name: Doris

texts.en:
Doris is a mother of two children ages 2 and 6 years. She has been farming for six years, producing tea, maize, bananas, and milk for the local market. She is 24 years of age and also engages in the lumbering business.

Doris has requested a loan of 47,100 Kenya shillings (KES) from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. She says that the profit she gains from this loan will enable her to educate her children. She also plans add two more dairy cows and buy her own power saw for the lumbering business.

She says occasional hailstones are a threat to farming in the area.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: 3.9.82 Thiệu Dương Group

texts.en:
Mrs Tính operates a food stall where she sells fruit. She is requesting a loan to purchase fruit to resell.

Tính is 43 years old and she is married with two children. She is the group leader of the 3.9.82 Thiệu D. solidarity group, which consists of five members. She lives and works in Thieu Hoa district, a semi-urban area in Thanh Hoa province, with two dependents.

In 2010, Tính joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to improve her business. Tính has successfully repaid two loans from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. Tính has been involved in this business for more than 10 years. The main hardship that Tính D. faces in her business is the lack of capital.

With her business profit, Tính hopes to make enough money to provide for her kids and to be able to buy more supplies and equipment for her business. She wants her family to be healthy and happy.

loans.use: to purchase fruit to resell.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth has been farming in the Litein area for eight years, producing and selling milk, tea, poultry, and potatoes to the local market. She is married with five children aged 14 to 18 years.

Elizabeth has made a loan request of 40,000 Kenya shillings (KES) from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase a chaff cutter to help her in feeding her dairy cows. She says improved dairy output will make life much better for her family members.

Elizabeth says lack of skills is the farmers main challenge, and she advocates for more farmer training.

loans.use: To purchase a chaff cutter for her dairy farm.

loans.name: Chelangat

texts.en:
Chelangat is 23 years old and has been farming for three years, producing and selling milk and potatoes to the local market. She is married with one child who is two years old. She buys and retails potatoes in the local market for additional income.

Chelangat has requested a loan of 30,000 Kenya shillings (KES) from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase more poultry birds for a poultry farming venture. She says this will compliment her dairy business and compensate for poor milk prices in the current market. She is optimistic about her poultry business and hopes her family's living standards will improve from the good return the business will make.

She sees fluctuation in market prices as the challenge in farming.

loans.use: To buy poultry birds.

loans.name: Anthony

texts.en:
Anthony is a farmer in Litein, South rift Kenya. He has been in farming for 18 years and currently produces milk and tea for the local market with the help of two farmhands. He is married with four children, two of whom are adults and the other two who are still schooling.

Anthony made a 50,000 Kenya shilling (KES) loan request through Kiva partner Juhudi Kilimo to help him construct a zero grazing (stall feeding) unit. He says this would improve his milk output and help him in running his hotel and butchery businesses in the local market and in turn educate his children.

Anthony notes that markets should be improved as they could be a challenge to farming business. He is also advocating for more farmer training.

loans.use: To construct a zero grazing unit.

loans.name: Moses

texts.en:
Moses is a farmer in Kitale, Western Kenya. He is married with four children ages 4 to 12 years. He has been farming for 15 years and currently employs one farmhand. His farm produces milk, maize, vegetables, and tomatoes.

He has requested a loan of 66,600 Kenya shillings (KES) from Juhudi Kilimo. He will purchase and insure a dairy cow for 41,600 KES and buy poultry birds for 25,000 KES. He says the loan will enable him expand his farming business and offer better quality of life to his family.

Moses also laments poor farm product prices in the market.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow and buy poulry birds.
